fix(firewall-config): invalid iterator

After removing and invalidating the iterator, break.

(cherry picked from commit 3c99625fa7180b0e53c08b82b9849d728f50e3b8)

fix(firewall-config): deprecation warnings

Fixes: #1054
(cherry picked from commit 9b632ef59e3fd986293172692bab0437f2199a50)

fix(iptables): allow loopback packets before conntrack checks

Fixes: 453717291b1d ("fix(iptables): drop invalid packets before zone dispatch")
(cherry picked from commit 5291e241f436d34da2e774d7ad7a97e4db27de52)

fix(nftables): allow loopback packets before conntrack checks

Some local proxies can do weird things over the loopback interface that
conntrack does not like, e.g. sport == dport.

Let's assume we can trust anything sent over the loopback interface.

Fixes: #1055
Fixes: e1d11e8691bf ("fix(nftables): drop invalid packets before zone dispatch")
(cherry picked from commit bc767151d6c36d610cebe756c52b0caf882d99b7)

fix(tcp-mss-clamp): duplicate rule fragments

Remove duplicate rich rule fragments and assign
default value to chain suffix variable.

(cherry picked from commit 892bd58148004b946d05c589bb1fc2adb7fa4926)
chore(release): v1.1.4

Revert "feat(service): Add jellyfin service"

This reverts commit 8c168d9eda5fd035d91422393ffea9b6ebcd2728.

As reported in [1], this causes an issue with RPMs shipped by Jellyfin.
This has been reported to firewalld in [2], where @joshuaboniface
stated that the Jellyfin project would like to remove the Jellyfin
config from firewalld, which is what this change does.

[1] https://github.com/jellyfin/jellyfin/issues/8587
[2] https://github.com/firewalld/firewalld/issues/1057

Closes: #1057

Signed-off-by: Christoph Müllner <cmuellner@gcc.gnu.org>
(cherry picked from commit 6fcbf890cfbc5e174308bc7dee7bf9d3eac4c95e)

test: avoid non-POSIX operator +=

(cherry picked from commit e1407b44abc1618165accca2744226e3f0f74627)

test: functions: command substitution cannot use only redirections

As noted in issue #1051, using only redirections inside $(command) is
unspecified.

As per POSIX [1]:

  With the $(command) form, all characters following the open
  parenthesis to the matching closing parenthesis constitute the
  command. Any valid shell script can be used for command, except a
  script consisting solely of redirections which produces unspecified
  results.

[1]: https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799.2018edition/

(cherry picked from commit b98bf02af417e661866dd213afda6f4dfd5f8033)

fix(iptables): drop invalid packets before zone dispatch

See previous commit message for details.

Fixes: #961
(cherry picked from commit 453717291b1d59197fa908237146bbcabc33e695)

fix(nftables): drop invalid packets before zone dispatch

Be strict about connection states.

Move the drop off invalid packets to occur before zone and policy
dispatch. Otherwise firewalld may allow these bogus packets through
which has odd results, e.g. packet sent but not masqueraded like other
packets.

Users that do want to allow INVALID packets through could allow them by
marking them NOTRACK before they hit firewalld's rules. This means
adding nftables/iptables rules out-of-band of firewalld. Note that these
packets would not be SNAT'd (masquerade) as that requires conntrack (or
stateless NAT rules, but firewalld doesn't provide those).

Fixes: #961
(cherry picked from commit e1d11e8691bf31d816ce556009a38bd7ebd40444)

test(ipset): verify native ipset creation is deferred

Until a direct rule is in use. Otherwise, add the set only to the active
FirewallBackend, e.g. nftables.

(cherry picked from commit f510855ae501675cfa828e313c58f194139dee79)

fix(ipset): defer native ipset creation if nftables

If using nftables (default), we can defer creating native ipsets until
direct rules are in use.

fix(policies): Splitting interfaces with wildcards

When creating a policy firewalld does not handle wildcard interfaces
(i.e. tun+). These interfaces need to be dealt with differently due to
the fact nftables cannot parse them in a 'set' (i.e. it will not
register a wildcard if given {"tun*", "net1"}).

This have been overcome through identifying the interfaces with
wildcards and splitting them out.

Before:
ifname { "eth0", "eth1" "tun+" } oifname { "eth1", "eth2" } jump filter_FWD_policy_test

After:
ifname "tun*" oifname { "eth1", "eth2" } jump filter_FWD_policy_test
ifname { "eth0", "eth1" } oifname { "eth1", "eth2" } jump filter_FWD_policy_test

(cherry picked from commit 3c3d06d49d585072ca8cd61f8b8bb2fcd62495e9)

fix(runtimeToPermanent): errors for interfaces not in zone

We should only consider the interfaces for the currently iterated over
zone. Otherwise we will attempt to remove an interface from a zone for
which it is does not belong.

Note this only occurs when NetworkManager is running.

Fixes: #976
Fixes: rhbz2112982

test(functions): remove bashism

On Debian derived systems, /bin/sh points to dash and not bash.
This leads to the following lintian error:

E: firewalld-tests: shell-script-fails-syntax-check [usr/share/firewalld/testsuite/integration/testsuite]
N:
N:   Running this shell script with the shell's -n option set fails, which means that the script has syntax errors.
N:   The most common cause of this problem is a script expecting /bin/sh to be bash checked on a system using dash as
N:   /bin/sh.
N:
N:   Run e.g. sh -n yourscript to see the errors yourself.
N:
N:   Note this can have false-positives, for an example with bash scripts using "extglob".
N:
N:   Visibility: error
N:   Show-Always: no
N:   Check: script/syntax
N:
N:
E: firewalld-tests: shell-script-fails-syntax-check [usr/share/firewalld/testsuite/testsuite]

Running sh -n points at the problem:

$ sh -n src/tests/testsuite
src/tests/testsuite: 58436: Syntax error: "(" unexpected (expecting ")")
$ sh -n src/tests/integration/testsuite
src/tests/integration/testsuite: 2082: Syntax error: "(" unexpected (expecting ")")

(cherry picked from commit c173474809fbdf72b86c0da77d571c8ea21ecdbc)

fix(io): service: verify included service exists

(cherry picked from commit d9ffd8331eddf9abe612f5d3dcdbc78a53820835)

fix(fw_icmptype): don't alter ipvs in io_object

We should never modify the runtime icmptype object. This caused sanity
failures on --runtime-to-permanent because the runtime icmptype
pretended to be ipv4 only, but our configuration (policy
allow-host-ipv6) used it inside an IPv6 only rich rule.

For users that disable IPv6 then this probably triggered an accidental
copy of the stock icmptype to a user icmptype, but with the ipv6 family
dropped.

(cherry picked from commit 9a9c9041a365fc8e12a3edf342de784cc5419a72)

(cherry picked from commit c122dd13f59abb17f6167ce6b16b604cae6d77df)

fix(build): oci: use dbus inside the container

Using the host's dbus requires the user to add a firewalld dbus policy
to the host.

It's better to keep the image self contained by starting dbus-daemon
inside the container. This means the container will not integrate with
dbus services on the host, e.g. NetworkManager.

Fixes: #925
(cherry picked from commit c7370b4238dae3f3ed9147cc70e743f4469338a6)

fix(build): oci: use centos:stream8 instead of ubi:8

ubi:8 doesn't actually have all the packages we need to build firewalld.

Fixes: #921
